bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, September 9, 1940

div1.p: Hutchison gives Hench details on the upcoming exercises honoring Lazear at Washington and Jefferson College, and discusses Hench's presentation. He encloses a list of addresses.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, September 9, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
September 9, 1940

div1.p:
This is supplementary to my letter of a day or
two ago since which time I have received your communica-
tion with the pictures and the notes. I have read the
notes through with intense interest. You have done an
enormous amount of work and it is all most interesting.
Your great problem will be that of reducing it to a
popular address.

The first thing of importance I want to say is
that the trustees have changed the plans and I am
authorized to invite you to give your talk at the Home-
coming Dinner on Saturday night, October the twenty-sixth,
instead of at the play the evening before. We believe
that the play will not be a good place for speaking, and
by making you the speaker of the evening at the dinner
it will give you a good opportunity. There will be a
couple of hundred or maybe three hundred people at the
dinner, it is the biggest dinner of the year here and you
and I will be the speakers, you making the main address,
and I finishing up with a short address on the college.
You should take about twenty minutes if you can condense
your material to put it across in that time. If you use
the stereopticon or moving pictures, it will take a little
more time of course for those, but the twenty minutes
would apply to the speaking. I am just explaining this
in order to suggest the kind of program which we have in
mind. In regard to the pictures, I will not take any now.
The Chemistry Building is not enough finished so that I can
tell where or how we can use them. I think we had better
leave that until after the occasion and after your use of
the pictures has shown which ones are the most interesting.

In regard to the publication of the story,
we do not have any W and J journal which would be substantial
enough to carry the detailed story which you should write.
I believe it would go better in some medical magazine
as your notes suggest, and I think you feel the same way.

You talk then would not be on yellow fever
primarily, but on Lazear, and only incidentally on yellow
fever. Doctor Sawyer will make the address in the morning
and will deal undoubtedly with the yellow fever in a general
way. I do not think that you need to worry about getting
into his territory if you stay by Lazear.

The fact that Doctor Finley graduated from
Jefferson Medical School in Philadelphia (if that's
what you mean) does give us a certain connection.
When Jefferson Medical School was founded, they could
not secure a charter and they therefore applied to
Jefferson College in Canonsburg to grant their degrees
for them which it did for a number of years. Jefferson
College was therefore instrumental and of assistance in
the founding of Jefferson Medical School, a relationship
of which we have been proud. In the same way, the
Baltimore School of Physicians and Surgeons was founded
by Washington College.

I am surprised to have your note of August
fifteenth stating that you are still looking for the
address of Mrs. Lazear. I am sure I sent it to you before
that but I will enclose it herewith.

The trustees have decided, in view of your
generous gift and the possibility that Mr. Pew may be
induced to pay the way of Moran - to invite both Kissinger
and Moran. I do not think we ought to invite Finlay's
son. In the first place we have as many people as we can
take care of, and in the second place this is a
glorification of Lazear and not Finley.

I will write the letter which you suggest
immediately to all of these people, excepting Moran,
to whom I wish to add some other things, and who is already
co-operating with you to the fullest extent. I still
think it is wiser for me to see Mr. Pew than to write him
and am planning to make a special trip to Philadelphia
for that purpose in the next week or so.

Of course we are expecting Mary to be here with
you!
I will be adding more later.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Hutch Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
